subject: Law
title: Trial by Ordeal and Its End
description: A micro-lesson that makes Trial by Ordeal and Its End usable.

hook.text: In medieval Europe, courts made suspects hold red-hot iron. If the wound healed, God proved your innocence.

buildup.text: Trial by ordeal relied on divine judgment: God would protect the innocent through fire, water, or combat.

discovery.text: Common ordeals included boiling water, hot iron, and cold water immersion. Priests supervised the process.

twist.text: In 1215, the Fourth Lateran Council banned clergy from participating. Without priests, the system collapsed.

climax.text: Courts turned to jury trials and rational evidence. The end of ordeal was the birth of modern trial procedure.

punchline.text: Justice moved from God's hands to human reasoning. That changed everything.

quiz.question: What ended the practice of trial by ordeal in Europe?
options: A plague killed all the judges
The Church banned clergy from participating
